11.25.22  7:05 am   Are the self-driving cats Teslas? Teslas have like some self-driving beta, if that would be why they were.

     none of the cars in the video are teslas. teslas are easy to recognize because they have no grill. all those cars have grills. the only reason there are no teslas in the video is because i didn't see any teslas when i was cruising around making a sample list. i'm somewhat surprised actually that there were no teslas. but maybe that's because i was searching mostly in the parking lots, which might have had older footage. or maybe they are just less popular in that region

     Also, can you describe the city of Perfect Heights?

     no curvature whatsoever

11.25.22  12:01 am   could you elaborate on the 'dos and donts of speech bubble placement'?

      sure. when the camera is very far away, obviously the speech bubble needs to be huge in the scene, in order to be a reasonable size on screen. And it needs to point directly to the characters. but the problem that sometimes happens is, there might be a tree or something closer to the camera than the character, which occupies the screenspace where the speech bubble goes. so if you put the speech bubble in the right place on the screen, it will either be partially obscured by the tree, or, it will disobey the laws of occlusion and be in front of the tree when it shouldn't be. I discovered that, if the camera is totally still, in most cases, you can get away with this. in other words, you can put a speech bubble which appears to point to the character on the 2D screenspace, even if its 3D placement would be impossible. in reality, it's actually a much smaller speech bubble, much closer to the camera, and its position is adjusted so it looks like it points to the character, even though if it were actually next to the character it would be behind the tree. So i've learned that you can usually get away with that when the camera is totally still. But when the camera is slightly moving, this absolutely does not work. There is a shot in the most recent video where the camera is across the street, looking toward the characters through the trees. To put the speech bubble actually next to the characters, it would be entirely obscured by the trees. If i cheat the speech bubble and put it in front of the trees, but smaller, this is a disaster because the camera is drifting slightly, and it becomes glaringly obvious that the bubble is much closer to the camera. So i tried to linearly keyframe the speech bubble to stay positioned next to the character, in 2D screen space. This is an even bigger disaster, and it looks like the scene is broken because the bubble is behaving as if it should be behind the tree, but it actually obscures the tree. Then i tried it with the speech bubble in the same place, but a longer stem reaching mostly back away from the camera toward the character. again, with the drifting camera, as the shape of the speech bubble is revealed, it looks truly bizarre. i ended up having place the bubble far off to the right, outside the trees, and make a very long tail on the 2D plane. which looks a little ridiculous and i didn't really want to do it that way, but i tried absolutely every other way, and it's the only thing that seemed to work. And i've also seen it done in comic books, so it's probably the best way

     if so, it would actually mean that they can't be happening at the same time. because the locations for this and the other video are hundreds of miles away

11.24.22  3:58 pm   where are the cars going in perfect

11.24.22  3:44 pm   Why did the orange shirt guy duck under the sign

      logistically, that was the only solution i could come up with to get to the right place at the right time. this is one of those puzzles that turns up when you actually get to the set. purple character climbs straight down and looks at the sign. orange character needs to immediately get to a vantage point of looking across the storefronts, while saying the next line. there are many 'bad' ways to do this. orange could climb down and walk directly through purple's line of sight.... this would seem to break purple's concentration. if orange climbs down and walks forward and around back of purple, this goes in between purple and the camera, which is distracting. another possibility is that orange could sort of slide to the side, on the sign, before jumping down. but that seems cumbersome and pointless. i also considered having orange jump off the back of the sign. but it would happen so quickly, i decided that that would look too much like accidental fall. climbing under the sign seemed to be the best way to solve all of this. with the added bonus that maybe he found the extra 'R' letters in the bushes there, under the sign
